{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3495567,"name":"","username":"AvocadoPeel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avocadopeel/{size}/232401_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-29T14:08:44.931Z","cooked":"

Has anyone here solved for or implemented swerve kinematics that takes in chassis speeds and chassis acceleration and calculates module states?

As i recall theres a post on here about second order kinematics but thats only the second order module states, not calculating for chassis acceleration.

This is admittedly not an important thing to code for, but im interested if anyone has done it.

This may be what you are remembering seeing:

Whitepaper: Swerve Drive Skew and Second Order Kinematics CD-Media: Papers
Team 449 made our first swerve drive a few months ago, and one of the first things we noticed is that when driving straight and spinning at the same time, the robot always skews in the direction of rotation. I’m sure many of you have also encountered this problem - if you’re wondering whether it’s happening because of an error in your code, the short answer is no. We spent a while trying to debug this issue, and through asking online we settled on the theory that since swerve constant translati…

yeah this one looks familiar, but im not so much concerned with skew, just accouning for desired chassis acceleration when calculating module states.

If you are ignoring module rotation, time, you can just use the normal rigid body acceleration kinematics to get wheel accel. If you want to also account for module rotation, uhh , good luck because its extremely hard and ugly.

The second order kinematics is what you would use to include desired robot acceleration. The basic gist is that in addition to commanding module velocity and angle, you could also command module acceleration and angular velocity (the first order derivative of the module state) which would let you fully control the second order derivative of the robot state. The paper breaks down the derivation, but the relevant snippets are:

Basic first order kinematics formula:

…

Field-relative linear module accelerations as a function of robot accelerations:

“Module-relative” module accelerations and angular velocity as a function of field relative module linear accelerations:

The paper is more thorough on the exact reference frames etc. I think the piece you’re looking for is the a_m value. You could also command the \omega_m value if you would like.

I make no guarantee on whether this actually makes a difference in performance at all, though, especially since it’s difficult to accurately control the module acceleration (and even its angular velocity). These formula were originally derived to a) identify the source of the skew and b) mathematically justify a linear relationship between angular velocity and skew angle via small angle approximation.
